ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great introduction into the thought-world of Benjamin, with concepts such as the dialectical image, the collector-allegorist, decline of the aura etc., which have impacted my own way of thinking and which concepts I will keep thinking about for a long time afterwards.
Understanding patterns and themes in archival projects. Really getting into a different time period. Parsing though dense concepts and theory.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I could get a bit lost when Prof Sussman entered into lecture mode, but the little that did gain was precious. I loved how he would make the Arcades Project relevant to modern life, from the bourgeois structure of American football to his obsession with Douglas Hofstadter.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. It's a shame that Sussman has retired.
